item.title: [LOG4J2-1246] PatternLayout %date conversion pattern should render time zone designator for ISO-ISO8601
item.description:
Hi there!

There might be a small issue with the Pattern Converters regarding Timezone management: http://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/manual/layouts.html#PatternLayout

Right now, these patterns:

  • "%d{ISO8601_BASIC}
  • %d{ISO8601_BASIC}{UTC}

Give the same results:

  • 20160104T204256,048
  • 20160104T204256,048

However, with a deeper look at the ISO-8601 standards, the second one with "{UTC}" should properly add the Timezone at the end of the timestamp.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Times

UTC
If the time is in UTC, add a Z directly after the time without a space. Z is the zone designator for the zero UTC offset. "09:30 UTC" is therefore represented as "09:30Z" or "0930Z". "14:45:15 UTC" would be "14:45:15Z" or "144515Z".
UTC time is also known as 'Zulu' time, since 'Zulu' is the NATO phonetic alphabet word for 'Z'.

Examples

<time>Z
<time>±hh:mm
<time>±hhmm
<time>±hh

As of ISO-8601, the results should be one of the following (configurable?):

  • 20160104T204256,048Z
  • 20160104T204256,048+00:00
  • 20160104T204256,048+0000
  • 20160104T204256,048+00

Another reference: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/833102/wheres-the-datetime-z-format-specifier

However, I do agree that by default, the timezone should be printed explicitly.
The current default promotes bad engineering and is the cause of endless frustration and loss of productivity when working with numerous logs.

Schneider it seems your example shows it works.

The issue is about missing timezone designator, the workaround is to append it in the layout manually.

I agree that the TZ should be there when you specify an ISO format. This does not work for me in the HEAD of 2.x-release:

      <PatternLayout pattern="%d{ISO8601}{UTC}Z [%t] %-5level: %msg%n%throwable" />

    <Logger name="org.foo" level="DEBUG" />

The problem here is that while {UTC} is used to identify the desired timezone the format string doesn't actually specify to include it. ISO8601 is shorthand for a pattern of yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss,SSS. To actually have the timezone included the pattern would have to end with Z. The simple solution is to replace ISO8601 with yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss,SSSZ

OK, so yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss,SSSZ gives me, for example, 2018-11-21T19:06:57,974-0700 but shouldn't I be able to say %d{ISO8601}{Z} or something like it?

Or, should we simply add an ISO8601_Z predefined format?
No. %d{ISO8601}{Z} doesn't make sense. The first operand is the date/time pattern. The second operand is the desired timezone to use. Adding ISO8601_Z would be a viable option.

OK, so what would I put in curlies to say "print the offset from UTC of the time zone my machine is running"?

I'll looking into adding ISO8601_Z.
You would put any valid timezone string. UTC would be valid.

You would put any valid timezone string. UTC would be valid.

That's not what I want. I want the local timestamp to be followed by the timezone offset just like I get when using "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss,SSSZ". From a user's POV "%d{ISO8101}

{Z}

Which leads me to adding ISO8601_Z but...

In org.apache.logging.log4j.core.util.datetime.FixedDateFormat.formatInstant(Instant, char[], int), there is no allowance for writing out a time zone offset like "-0700". Am I missing something?

It appears to me that Remko wrote FixedDateFormat as an optimization. Since none of the patterns that are defined in that class include a timezone I don't think he included support for it. If a pattern is used that is not one of the ones defined in the FixedFormat enum it looks like DatePatternConverter falls back to the original code which does support a timezone.

As for what the value of the timezone data is, from what I understand it may be in any of the following formats:

<time>Z
<time>±hh:mm
<time>±hhmm
<time>±hh

and it doesn't look like the user has much control over the format.

Also, I would suggest we should support all of the constants listed at https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html.

Also, when I said any valid timezone I meant something like

{yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss.SSSZ}(America/Phoenix}

This means the date would be formatted to look like 2018-11-22T10:31:15.123-07:00.

In other words {Z} makes no sense as the second parameter as it is not a valid timezone.
The patch in my previous comment adds a "ISO8101_Z" to this FixedDateFormat but I do not see how the patter is actually used, if it actually is. remkop@yahoo.com?

ralph.goers@dslextreme.com said:

Also, I would suggest we should support all of the constants listed at https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html.

Before we go down that path, it would be good to take a close look at Java 8's java.time package. I would not want to create and maintain a pile of code in Log4j 2.x that would not need to exist in 3.x.

Yes, FixedDateFormat is an optimization. It’s significantly faster than SimpleDateFormat. Additionally it’s thread safe (non-blocking) and garbage free. It doesn’t support all the formats that Java supports.

I believe that it should fall back to a Java standard formatter if the user specified a format that it cannot handle. So, not adding time zone support to the FixedDateFormat class is a valid option.

Hi remkop@yahoo.com,

Are you available to implement ISO8601_Z? Please see WIP patch in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-1246?focusedCommentId=16696119&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16696119

WRT garbage free: I do not see how FixedDateFormat is garbage free when I see org.apache.logging.log4j.core.util.datetime.FixedDateFormat.formatInstant(Instant):

    public String formatInstant(final Instant instant) {
        final char[] result = new char[length << 1]; // double size for locales with lengthy DateFormatSymbols

Gary, the easy fix for this is to create an enum in DatePatternConverter that is similar to FixedFormat containing the patterns you want to support. Then in DatePatternConverter.createNonFixedFormatter see if the passed pattern matches one of then enum patterns and if so pass the pattern associated with the enum to FastDateFormat.getInstance().

Although Remko mentions it above, I don't think FixedDateFormat was intended to be garbage free as it allocates temporary stuff in several places. But because it supports a limited set of patterns he was able to improve its performance. Since the timezone isn't one of the supported patterns I think you should be ignoring that class for this issue.

The main code path is garbage-free. The method called from DatePatternFormat.FixedFormatter.formatToBuffer(Instant, StringBuilder) is FixedDateFormat.formatInstant(Instant, char[], int), which does not allocate after FixedDateFormat is fully initialized. Log4j could not claim to be garbage-free without FixedDateFormat.

I'm fine with Ralph's suggestion to use FastDateFormat for time zone support. I don't know when I'll have time to work on FixedDateFormat.

Thank you both for your replies. I am trying to follow the bouncing ball here but it seems to me the simpler path is to add ISO8601_Z right next to ISO8601 in org.apache.logging.log4j.core.util.datetime.FixedDateFormat.FixedFormat. Why add an enum to DatePatternConverter when there is already one with a near exact pattern to what I want already in FixedFormat? I must be missing something. It seems that FastDateFormat would need to be updated to support "Z" no matter what, right?

remkop@yahoo.com I am not sure what is wrong with the example Gary provided. -0700 is a valid timezone. It happens to match the one I am in - Phoenix, AZ, USA.

As you pointed out, using Z in the name is not a great idea as it is equivalent to UTC or GMT when included in a time value. But Java lets you use it in a format string to identify that you want a timezone in the format, which is why Gary probably used that name. So if meant to identify that this pattern includes the timezone then the example is fine.

I know -0700 is a valid timezone. However, that value 2012-11-02'T'14:34:02,781-0700 is the result of using the ISO8601_WITH_TIMEZONE_HHMM format to render a timestamp. When we render the timestamp in the ISO8601_WITH_TIMEZONE_Z format it should show time in UTC, so with offset zero. To clarify that this is UTC and has offset zero, the resulting string may end in either "Z", "+00", "+0000" or "+00:00".

However this is minor. I think renaming the enum constants in FixedDateFormat is more important (see previous comment).

I agree with the renaming constants, but I still don't agree that it needs to show UTC. If the server is configured with your local timezone than using "Z" in the pattern will cause the local timezone value to be included in the output. IOW - if I call java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter with a pattern of ISO_OFFSET_DATE_TIME or its equivalent pattern "yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ssZ" on my computer I will see it append -0700 (or possibly -07:00) to the time.

I thought we had a feature request not that long ago to allow rendering all timestamps in UTC (with offset zero) to assist with the user's aggregation of globally distributed log files.
I thought we would use ISO8601_WITH_TIMEZONE_Z to implement this feature request, where other formats would show local time with the offset in one of the HH, HHmm or HH:mm formats.
I could be mistaken.
If we do that then I would suggest UTC should be used in the name of the constant rather than Z, as Z is obviously ambiguous.
Ah yes, UTC is a better idea.

A quick note before I retire for the night: I like "OFFSET" in the new names because it comes from the Java names AND more importantly it should make it absolutely clear that these formats are  not going to output timestamps in UTC.

Okay if we are not going to support outputting timestamps in UTC then maybe we should not have a format constant that ends in Z to avoid confusion.

About the other constant names, I think it’s crucial that they have the word “time zone” in them somehow. (Offset is more of an implementation detail.)

Can we make these changes:

  • Our javadoc should show an example of a resulting timestamp as it will appear in the log file
  • Can we rename our current constant names that end in X, XX or XXX to something more meaningful? I propose using HH when the timezone offset is rendered as +10 (e.g. 2012-11-02'T'14:34:02,781+10), HHMM when the timezone offset is rendered as +1000 (e.g. 2012-11-02'T'14:34:02,781+1000) and HH_MM when the timezone offset is rendered as +10:00 (e.g. 2012-11-02'T'14:34:02,781+10:00)
  • Can we remove the constant that ends in Z (ISO8601_OFFSET_DATE_TIME_Z and FixedTimeZoneFormat.Z) to avoid confusion? Users are likely to assume that these formats will render "Zulu time", that is, UTC time.
  • Where our constant names have a DateTimeFormatter equivalent its Javadoc should link to constant in DateTimeFormatter (I suspect only ISO_OFFSET_DATE_TIME has an exact match in our constants)
